sen.j: 平氏（へいし、たいらうじ）は、皇族が臣下に下る際に賜るカバネの一つ、「平朝臣」を姓とする臣籍降下。
sen.e: The Taira clan is the clan who was bestowed the surname of 'TAIRA no Ason,' one of the kabane (official status title), at the time of demotion from the Imperial family to subject.
The surname of 'TAIRA no Ason was received by part of the imperial family on their demotion from the imperial family to become subjects, and was one of the kabane (official status title).
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: The family name of the Taira clan was derived from "TAIRA no Ason," which was one of the official titles given to a member of the Imperial Family if they became vassals.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 家紋は揚羽蝶など。
sen.e: Its family crest was swallowtail butterfly and so on.
The family crest includes a swallowtail (butterfly).
sen.cmt: "and so on" is a little unnatural here.
sen.e: A swallowtail butterfly was the representative Kamon (family crest) of the Taira clan.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。。swallowtailedを訂正しました。family crest→Kamon (family crest)に変更

sen.j: 源氏と同じく、皇子皇女の処遇として賜姓が行われたが、天皇の孫以降の代に賜姓を受けた例が多いと言われ、そのため源氏よりも格は下とされる。
sen.e: The shinsei (bestowing a surname) of the Taira clan was made as a treatment of prince and princess as well as the Minamoto clan, but its status was regarded lower than the one of the Minamoto clan because shinsei was often made against the later generation of the grandchild of emperor.

Shinsei (bestowal of a surname) was applied to imperial princes and princesses to create theTaira Clan, just as it had created the Minamoto clan, but in the case of the Taira it was said to have been practiced on generations later than the grandchildren of the emperor, and the Taira clan were therefore seen to be of lower rank than the Minamoto clan.
sen.cmt: Rewrote for clarity
sen.e: While the family names of Minamoto and Taira were both conferred on princes and princesses, many of those who received the title of Taira were said to have been the emperor's grandchildren or more distant relatives; therefore, the Taira clan was considered to hold a lower rank than the Minamoto clan.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。I'm not really sure what "or later generations" is supposed to mean here. I assume it means "more distant relatives".

sen.j: 「平」という名称の由来は不明であるが、もっとも有力な説は太田亮が唱えて藤木邦彦・佐伯有清らが発展させた説で、最初の平氏であった桓武平氏の祖である桓武天皇が建設した平安京にちなんで「平（和訓多比良）」と名づけたとするものである。
sen.e: The origin of the name 'Taira' is not known, but the most influential theory is the one begun by Akira OTA and developed by Kunihiko FUJIKI, Arikiyo SAEKI and others, that is, it was named after the Heian-kyo (the ancient capital of Japan in current Kyoto) which was established by the Emperor Kanmu who was the ancestor of Kanmu-Heishi, the first Taira clan.

The origin of the name 'Taira' is unknown, but the most influential theory, as proposed by Akira OTA and developed by Kunihiko FUJIKI, Arikiyo SAEKI and others, is that it derives from a Japanese reading of the "Hei" character in Heian-kyo (present-day Kyoto), which was built by Emperor Kanmu, an ancestor of Kanmu-Heishi, the first of the Taira.
sen.cmt: Trans1 ignores （和訓多比良）. I have translated this as a "Japanese reading of the "Hei" character but this needs checking.
sen.e: While the origin of the name 'Taira' is unknown, the most influential theory proposed by Akira OTA and developed by Kunihiko FUJIKI, Arikiyo SAEKI and others, states that "Taira" derives from a Japanese reading of the kanji character "平" in "平安京," the ancient capital in present-day Kyoto which was built by the Emperor Kanmu, an ancestor of the first Taira clan, Kanmu-Heishi.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: また、安田政彦はこの説を支持しつつも、源氏・在原氏と同様に中国古典からの出典も存在した可能性について指摘している。
sen.e: In addition, with supporting this theory, Masahiko YASUDA also points out the possibility of the origin from Chinese classics as same as the Minamoto clan and the Ariwara clan.
Masahiko YASUDA also supports this theory but makes the point that the name could have come from the Chinese classics in the same way as the Minamoto Ariwara names.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: Masahiko YASUDA also supports this theory but makes the point that the name could also have come from the Chinese classics, as the names of Minamoto and Ariwara clans did.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 桓武天皇から出た桓武平氏、仁明天皇から出た仁明平氏、文徳天皇から出た文徳平氏、光孝天皇から出た光孝平氏の四流ある。
sen.e: There were four lineage of the Taira clan as follows; the Kanmu-Heishi originated from the Emperor Kanmu, Ninmyo-Heishi originated from the Emperor Ninmyo, Montoku-Heishi originated from Montoku and Koko-Heishi originated from the Emperor Koko.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: There were four Taira clan lineages; the Kanmu-Heishi descended from Emperor Kanmu, Ninmyo-Heishi descended from Emperor Ninmyo, Montoku-Heishi descended from Emperor Montoku, and Koko-Heishi descended from Emperor Koko.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: There were four Taira clan lineages; the Kanmu-Heishi descended from Emperor Kanmu, Ninmyo-Heishi (Taira clan) descended from Emperor Ninmyo, Montoku-Heishi (Taira clan) descended from Emperor Montoku, and Koko-Heishi (Taira clan) descended from Emperor Koko.
sen.cmt: 「(Taira clan)」を補足しました。

sen.j: 武家平氏として子孫の活躍が知られるのは平氏政権を作った平家（平清盛の家）を出した伊勢平氏や、鎌倉幕府の執権北条氏を出した坂東平氏などの桓武平氏のみである。
sen.e: Among them, only the lineage of Kanmu-Heishi such as Ise-Heishi, the origin of the Taira family (the family of TAIRA no Kiyomori) that established the government of the Taira clan, and Bando-Heishi, the origin of the Hojo clan who was the regent of the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) is famous for their descendants' prosperity as samurai family, so that generally the word "Taira clan" means Kanmu-Heishi.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Of these, the only lineage to produce famous samurai families was the Kanmu-Heishi lineage which included Ise-Heishi, the originator of the Taira family which established the Taira government (the family of TAIRA no Kiyomori), and Bando-Heishi, the originator of the Hojo clan who became regents of the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), and thus "Taira clan" generally refers to the Kanmu-Heishi lineage.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: Of these, the only lineage to produce famous samurai families was the Kanmu-Heishi lineage, which included the following branches: the Ise-Heishi, from which the Heike (the family of TAIRA no Kiyomori that established the Taira clan government) was descended; and the Bando-Heishi, from which the Hojo clan (which became regents of the Kamakura bakufu, a Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) was descended.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。一原文一訳文例外対処

sen.j: 一般に平氏といえば桓武平氏を指すことが多い。
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: This is the reason why the Taira clan generally refers to the Kanmu-Heishi lineage.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。一原文一訳文例外対処

sen.j: 一般的に「東国の源氏、西国の平氏」と言われるが、東国に平氏が全くいなかったわけではない。
sen.e: It is generally said that 'The Minamoto clan in Togoku (the eastern part of Japan, particularly Kanto region) and the Taira clan in Saigoku (the western part of Japan (esp. Kyushu, but ranging as far east as Kinki)),' but it is not necessarily mean that there was no Taira clan in Togoku.

It is conventional to talk about 'The Minamoto clan of Togoku (the eastern part of Japan, particularly Kanto region) and the Taira clan of Saigoku (the western part of Japan (esp. Kyushu, but ranging as far east as Kinki)),' but this is not to say that there were no Taira clan in Togoku.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: It is generally believed that the Minamoto clan ruled the Togoku (the eastern part of Japan, particularly the Kanto region), while the Taira clan held power in the Saigoku (the western part of Japan, particularly Kyushu but ranging as far east as Kinki), but members of the Taira clan could also be found in the Togoku as well.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: むしろ親王任国が集中した東国が平氏系武士の盤踞地で、その一族がその後、中央（朝廷）に勢力を伸ばし、西国にも平氏勢力が広がっていったという方が適切である。
sen.e: It is rather more adequate to say that Togoku, where many princes governed, was the home ground of the samurai of the Taira clan, and that it spread its power to the central government (the Imperial court) later and to Saigoku as well.

In fact, it would be more appropriate to say that Togoku, where many princes governed, was home ground for the samurai of Taira lineage, and one of these families later expanded their influence to the center (the Imperial court) and to Saigoku.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: In fact, it would be more appropriate to say that the influence of the samurai of Taira lineage first covered the Togoku where many imperial princes were appointed to the governors of provinces, and later the Taira clan expanded their sphere of influence to the center (the Imperial court) and to the Saigoku.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 著名な平氏出身者としては例えば東国に独立政権を樹立しようとして失敗した下総国・常陸国の平将門、時代が下って貴族政権で台頭した平清盛の先祖も東国出身の土着平氏であり、これを倒した源頼朝を支えた坂東平氏も同じ土着系平氏の末裔であった。
sen.e: The famous examples of the Taira clan are as follows; TAIRA no Masakado in the Shimofusa and Hitachi Provinces who tried to establish an independent government in Togoku but failed, and the ancestors of TAIRA no Kiyomori who had a power in the aristocratic government in later age, had an origin of the local Taira clan in Togoku, and the Bando-Heishi who supported MINAMOTO no Yoritomo that defeated him was the descendant of the same local Taira clan.

Famous members of the Taira clan include: TAIRA no Masakado of Shimofusa and Hitachi Provinces who tried but failed to establish an independent government in Togoku; the Togoku-native ancestors of TAIRA no Kiyomori who led the aristocratic government; and, also descended from the Tohoku-native lineage, the Bando-Heishi that supported MINAMOTO no Yoritomo after he had toppled Kiyomori.
sen.cmt: Not sure what "これ" refers to the in the original but have assumed that it refers to the 貴族政権.
sen.e: Famous members of the Taira clan included the following: TAIRA no Masakado of Shimousa Province and Hitachi Province, who tried but failed to establish an independent government in Togoku; TAIRA no Kiyomori, who led the aristocratic government; and the Bando-Heishi, supporters of MINAMOTO no Yoritomo, who had toppled Kiyomori; ironically, both Kiyomori and the Bando-Heishi could trace their ancestry back to the lineage of the Taira clan that was native to the Togoku.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: この時の源平氏族のこと争いを「源氏と平氏」ではなく、「源氏と平家（平清盛の一族）」と呼ばれ区別されるのはこのためでる。
sen.e: This is the reason why this conflict between the Minamoto and the Taira clans is not called the conflict between 'the Minamoto clan and the Taira clan' but called the one between 'the Minamoto clan and Heike (a family of TAIRA no Kiyomori)' and distinguished from it.

This is why the conflict between the Minamoto and the Taira clans at this time is not called the 'conflict between the Minamoto clan and the Taira clan' but rather 'the conflict between the Minamoto clan and Heike (family of TAIRA no Kiyomori)'.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: This shared ancestry is the reason why the conflict is referred to as 'the conflict between the Minamoto clan and Heike (family of TAIRA no Kiyomori),' not as the 'conflict between the Minamoto clan and the Taira clan.'
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 西暦600～700年にかけて律令制の導入に成功した藤原氏、特に藤原北家が東国においてもその基盤を確立した（宇都宮氏、小田氏、那須氏、小山氏、結城氏、佐野氏、比企氏等）。
sen.e: The Fujiwara clan who made success in the introduction of the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) around 600-700, especially the Northern House of the Fujiwara clan, also established its base in Togoku (the Utsunomiya clan, the Oda clan, the Nasu clan, the Koyama clan, the Yuki clan, the Sano clan, the Hiki clan and so on).

The Fujiwara clan who successfully introduced the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) over the period 600-700, specifically the Northern House of the Fujiwara clan, established a base in Togoku (the Utsunomiya clan, the Oda clan, the Nasu clan, the Koyama clan, the Yuki clan, the Sano clan, the Hiki clan etc).
sen.cmt: Readers may not know what the 'Ritsuryo code' is. This requires further explanation. Also it is not clear what links the various clans mentioned here had with the base.
sen.e: The Fujiwara clan successfully introduced the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) between the years 600 and 700; specifically, one of the Fujiwara clan lines, the Northern House of the Fujiwara clan, established its foundations in Togoku (the Utsunomiya clan, the Oda clan, the Nasu clan, the Koyama clan, the Yuki clan, the Sano clan, the Hiki clan, etc.).
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。Hokke→the Northern House of the Fujiwara clanに変更

sen.j: なおヤマト王権は大宝律令の編纂に先じて東国下野国（現在の栃木県）の国造・下毛野君の一族である下野宇都宮氏下毛野氏を召集し、藤原不比等と伴に律令編纂に従事させている。
sen.e: In addition, before the editing of Taiho Code, the Yamato sovereignty (the ancient Japan sovereignty) called the Shimotsuke-Utsunomiya clan and the Shimotsukenu clan, a clan of Shimotsukenu no kimi who was Kuni no miyatsuko (Local ruling families in ancient Japan) in the Shimotsuke Province (present Tochigi Prefecture) in Togoku, and made them edit the Ritsuryo codes with FUJIWARA no Fuhito.

Before the editing Taiho Code, the Yamato kingdom (ancient kingdome of Japan) invited the Shimotsuke-Utsunomiya clan and the Shimotsukenu clan, which were the clans of SHIMOTSUKENU no kimi and the local ruling families in Shimotsuke Province (present-day Tochigi Prefecture) in Togoku, and had them edit the Ritsuryo codes with FUJIWARA no Fuhito.
sen.cmt: Trans 1 is difficult to understand. I have tried to improve it, but further work is required. It is not really clear what the point of this sentence is. Also, an explanation of the Taiho coded is required.
sen.e: Prior to the compilation of Taiho Code, the Yamato kingdom (ancient kingdom of Japan) summoned SHIMOTSUKENU no Komaro who was a member of the local ruling family SHIMOTSUKENU in Shimotsuke Province (present-day Tochigi Prefecture) in Togoku, to be engaged in compilation of the codes with FUJIWARA no Fuhito.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: その後、第50代桓武天皇から派生した桓武平氏は東国を親王任国として自領化していった（常陸国・上総国・上野国）。
sen.e: After that, the Kanmu-Heishi originated from the 50th Emperor Kanmu made Togoku its territory as shinno ninkoku (provinces whose guvernatorial posts were reserved as sinecures for imperial princes) (the Hitachi Province, the Kazusa Province and the Ueno Province).

Thereafter, the Kanmu-Heishi, which was descended from with the 50th Emperor Kanmu, took over Togoku (Hitachi Province, Kazusa Province and Ueno Province) by making use of the shinno ninkoku system (under which guvernatorial posts were reserved for imperial princes).
sen.cmt: Again trans1 and the original are ambiguous. What does "新王任国として" mean?
sen.e: Thereafter, the Kanmu-Heishi, which was descended from the fiftieth Emperor Kanmu, took over Togoku (Hitachi Province, Kazusa Province and Kozuke Province) by appointing imperial princes to the governors of the provinces.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: この自領化が平安時代末期の平氏台頭の後押しをしたと言われる。
sen.e: It is said that this expansion of the territory promoted the prosperity of the Taira clan in the end of the Heian period.
This expansion of the territory is said to have boosted the power of the Taira clan in the end of the Heian period.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: It is considered that this expansion of their own territory supported the rise of the Taira clan in the late Heian period.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 坂東平氏として著名なのは、鎌倉氏、三浦氏、千葉氏、上総氏、秩父氏、大掾氏、中村氏、長尾氏、梶原氏等である。
sen.e: The famous Bando-Heishi are the Kamakura clan, the Miura clan, the Chiba clan, the Kazusa clan, the Chichibu clan, the Daijo clan, the Nakamura clan, the Nagao clan, the Kajiwara clan and so on.

The famous Bando-Heishi included the Kamakura clan, the Miura clan, the Chiba clan, the Kazusa clan, the Chichibu clan, the Daijo clan, the Nakamura clan, the Nagao clan, the Kajiwara clan and others.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: The famous Bando-Heishi clans included the Kamakura, Miura, Chiba, Kazusa, Chichibu, Daijo, Nakamura, Nagao, and Kajiwara.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 一方で第56代清和天皇から派生した清和源氏、特に武家棟梁と呼ばれる畿内の河内国を本拠地とした河内源氏の一族は特権階級（平氏や藤原氏等）の増長を制し、着々と東国にその基盤を広げて行った。
sen.e: On the other hand, the clans such as Seiwa-Genji (Minamoto clan) who was originated from the 56th Emperor Seiwa and especially Kawachi-Genji (Minamoto clan) who was based on the Kawachi Province in Kinai region (the five capital provinces surrounding the ancient capitals of Nara and Kyoto) and was called the head of the samurai families, stopped the empowerment of the privileged class and gradually spread the basement in Togoku.

Meanwhile, the Seiwa-Genji (Minamoto clan) descended from the 56th Emperor Seiwa, and in particular the Kawachi-Genji (Minamoto clan) which was called the head of the samurai families and was based in Kawachi Province in Kinai region (the five capital provinces surrounding the ancient capitals of Nara and Kyoto), stopped the empowerment of the privileged classes (the Taira, Fujiwara etc.) and steadily expanded their power base in Togoku.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: Meanwhile, the Seiwa-Genji branch of the Minamoto clan (who were descended from Emperor Seiwa, the fifty-sixth emperor) and particularly the Kawachi-Genji branch of the Minamoto clan (which was known as the head of the samurai families based in Kawachi Province, which was located in the Kinai region) prevented the privileged classes (clans such as the Taira and Fujiwara) from assuming power and steadily extended the power base of the Minamoto clan throughout the Togoku.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。56thをスペルアウトしました。At times explanatory information such as "the five capital provinces surrounding the ancient capitals of Nara and Kyoto" may be essential, but here including this level of detail results in a sentence that is almost impossible to read because of the amount of supplementary information separating the subject from the verb.

sen.j: 河内源氏の流れを汲む坂東の源氏として著名なのは新田氏、足利氏、佐竹氏、武田氏、小笠原氏、里見氏等である。
sen.e: The famous Bando-Heishi originated from the Kawachi-Genji are the Nitta clan, the Ashikaga clan, the Satake clan, the Takeda clan, the Ogasawara clan, the Satomi clan and so on.
The famous Bando-Heishi drawn from the Kawachi-Genji included the Nitta clan, the Ashikaga clan, the Satake clan, the Takeda clan, the Ogasawara clan, and the Satomi clan.
sen.cmt: Used "included" to avoid using "and so on".
sen.e: The famous Minamoto clans in the Bando (old Kanto) region descended from the Kawachi-Genji included the Nitta, Ashikaga, Satake, Takeda, Ogasawara, and Satomi.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 結果的に坂東平氏は源氏一門や藤原氏一門に恭順し家臣となるか、あるいは抵抗して追討されるなどして、東国史上華々しい成果を収めなかったのに対し、伊勢平氏の平清盛は西国を制して中央政権を牛耳った。
sen.e: While the Bando-Heishi obeyed the Genji clan and Fujiwara clan as their retainer or was defeated after resistance and consequently they did not show great results in Togoku history, TAIRA no Kiyomori of the Ise-Heishi ruled Saigoku and the central government.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In the final assessment, the Bando-Heishi either became retainers for the the Genji clan or Fujiwara clan, or were crushed after offering resistance, and do not therefore stand tall in the history of Togoku; TAIRA no Kiyomori of the Ise-Heishi, on the other hand ruled Saigoku and led the central government.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: Families of the Bando-Heishi clan either became retainers for or rebelled against and suppressed by the Genji and Fujiwara clans, and thus hardly left their marks on the history of Togoku, while TAIRA no Kiyomori who came from the Ise-Heishi ruled Saigoku and controlled the central government.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: これに抗した河内源氏流の坂東源氏・源頼朝が平氏を追討して東国に鎌倉幕府を開き、さらに後醍醐天皇の意向を受けた新田義貞・足利尊氏が坂東平氏に乗っ取られた鎌倉幕府を倒して新たな中央政権樹立に貢献したこと、さらに鎌倉幕府・室町幕府・江戸幕府揃って坂東源氏の政権であったことなどあった。
sen.e: Against it, MINAMOTO no Yoritomo, the Bando-Heishi originated from Kawachi-Genji, expelled the Taira clan and founded the Kamakura bakufu in Togoku, Yoshisada NITTA and Takauji ASHIKAGA, who were ordered by the Emperor Godaigo, defeated the Kamakura bakufu which was taken over by Bando-Heishi and contributed to building up the new central government, and furthermore, the Kamakura bakufu, the Muromachi bakufu and the Edo bakufu were all the governments of the Bando-Heishi.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: MINAMOTO no Yoritomo of the Bando-Genji drawn from Kawachi-Genji crushed the Taira clan and founded the Kamakura bakufu in Togoku; Yoshisada NITTA and Takauji ASHIKAGA, under orders from Emperor Godaigo, toppled the Kamakura bakufu of the Bando-Heishi and contributed to establishing a new central government; moreover, the Kamakura bakufu, the Muromachi bakufu and the Edo bakufu were all Bando-Genji governments.
sen.cmt: Trans1 confuses Genji and Heishi.
sen.e: After MINAMOTO no Yoritomo, who was descended from the Bando-Genji line of the Kawachi-Genji, rebelled against and defeated the Taira clan, he founded the Kamakura bakufu in Togoku, but Yoshisada NITTA and Takauji ASHIKAGA, under orders from Emperor Godaigo, toppled the Kamakura bakufu, which had been taken over by the Bando-Heishi, and contributed to the establishment of a new central government; moreover, the Kamakura, Muromachi and Edo bakufu were feudal governments administered by the Bando-Genji.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。This now reflects what the Japanese says but this should really be broken into two sentences as below because, as a single sentence, this just reads as if as much information as possible has been almost randomly thrown into one sentence.After MINAMOTO no Yoritomo, who was descended from the Bando-Genji line of the Kawachi-Genji, rebelled against and defeated the Taira clan, he founded the Kamakura bakufu in Togoku, but Yoshisada NITTA and Takauji ASHIKAGA, under orders from Emperor Godaigo, toppled the Kamakura bakufu, which had been taken over by the Bando-Heishi, and contributed to the establishment of a new central government. The Bando-Genji administered not only the Kamakura bakufu, but also the Muromachi and Edo bakufu.

sen.j: これが「東国の源氏、西国の平氏」と言わしめている所以であろう。
sen.e: Those seem to be the reasons of the words 'The Minamoto clan in Togoku and the Taira clan in Saigoku.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: This is probably why we talk about 'The Minamoto clan of Togoku and the Taira clan of Saigoku.
sen.cmt: The above sectoin is likely to be very confusing to an reader of English because it the Taira/Heishi and Minamoto/Genji correspondence is unclear.
sen.e: These facts are probably the basis of general belief that the Minamoto clan ruled the Togoku while the Taira clan had influence over the Saigoku.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 平姓を残したのは伊勢平氏など数少ない。
sen.e: A few clan such as the Ise-Heishi remained the surname of Taira.
Only a few clans retained Taira surname, but these included the Ise-Heishi clan.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: Only a few clans, such as the Ise-Heishi, retained the Taira surname (the same kanji character is used for both "Hei" and "Taira.")
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: その伊勢平氏の傍流であったが、いわゆる平氏政権を打ち立てた平清盛とその一族を特に“平家”（へいけ）と呼ぶ。
sen.e: Although it was a branch of the Ise-Heishi, TAIRA no Kiyomori who established the so-called Heishi government and his family, were especially called 'Heike (the Taira family).'
Although he came from a branch of the Ise-Heishi, TAIRA no Kiyomori, who established the so-called Heishi government, and his family were called the 'Heike (the Taira family).'
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: Although it was a branch of the Ise-Heishi clan, the term 'Heike' (Taira family) specifically refers to TAIRA no Kiyomori, who established the so-called Heishi government, and members of his family.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: これに対して源氏は、源姓を名のった一族は多く、源家は複数になるため、通常は、源家総体という意味での源氏と呼び、源家という言い方はあまり用いない。
sen.e: As opposed to this, many families of the Minamoto clan used the surname of Minamoto, which led to many Minamoto families, so that it is usually called Genji (the Minamoto clan) instead of Genke (the Minamoto family).

In contrast, since many families of the Minamoto clan used the Minamoto surname and there are many Minamoto families, they are collectively referred to as Genji (the Minamoto clan), and the term Genke (the Minamoto family) is rarely used.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: In contrast, many families of the Minamoto clan used the Minamoto surname and were collectively referred to as Genji (the Minamoto clan); and the term Genke, referring to a single Minamoto family, is rarely used.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 桓武平氏（かんむへいし）は、天長2年（825年）以降に桓武天皇の孫たちのうち身分の低い者が、「平朝臣」を賜姓されて臣籍に下ることによって成立した氏族である。
sen.e: The Kanmu-Heishi was the clan originated from the lower class of the descendants the Emperor Kanmu after 825 who was bestowed the surname of 'TAIRA no Ason' at the time of demotion from the Imperial family to subject.
The Kanmu-Heishi were born from 825 onwards out of the lower ranks of the descendants of the Emperor Kanmu, who were bestowed the surname of 'TAIRA no Ason' on being demoted from the Imperial family.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: The Kanmu-Heishi were established by some lower ranked grandsons of Emperor Kanmu who had been given the honorary surname of 'TAIRA no Ason' upon being demoted from the Imperial family in and after 825.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 始祖とする桓武天皇の皇子によって大きく四流に分かれる。
sen.e: They are roughly classified into four lineages depending on its founder prince of the Emperor Kanmu.
They can be broadly classified into four lineages according to which of the princes descended from Emperor Kanmu was the founder.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: They can be broadly classified into four lineages according to the founders who were sons of the Emperor Kanmu.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 繁栄したのは葛原親王の流れであるが、その他、万多親王流・仲野親王流及び賀陽親王流の三つの流れがある。
sen.e: The most prosperous lineage was the one of the Imperial Prince Kazurawara, and there are other three lineages of the Imperial Prince Manda, the Imperial Prince Nakano and the Imperial Prince Kaya.
The most prosperous lineage was that of Imperial Prince Kazurawara, the other three lineages being those of Imperial Prince Manda, Imperial Prince Nakano and Imperial Prince Kaya.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: The most prosperous lineage was that of Imperial Prince Kazurawara, and the other three lineages were those of Imperial Prince Manda, Imperial Prince Nakano and Imperial Prince Kaya.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

tit.e: The lineage of the Imperial Prince Kazurawara
The lineage of Imperial Prince Kazurawara
The lineage of Imperial Prince Kazurawara

sen.j: 桓武平氏四流のうちの一つであり、葛原親王流には葛原親王の長男高棟王が臣籍降下し平高棟となった公家の高棟王流と、三男の高見王ととも高見王の子高望王が臣籍降下し平高望となった武家の高望王流の二流が知られる。
sen.e: It is one of the four lineages of the Kanmu-Heishi and the following two lineages are well-known; the Prince Takamune linage originated from the Prince Takamune, who was the first son of the Imperial Prince Kazurawara and identified himself as TAIRA no Takamune by the demotion from the Imperial family to subject, and the Prince Takamochi linage, a samurai family, originated from the Prince Takamochi who was the son of the Prince Takami (the third son of the Emperor Kanmu) and identified himself as TAIRA no Takamochi by the demotion from the Imperial family to subject with his father.

This is one of the four Kanmu-Heishi lineages and has itself the following two well-known lineages: the Prince Takamune lineage which originates from Prince Takamune, who was the first son of the Imperial Prince Kazurawara and identified himself as TAIRA no Takamune on demotion from the Imperial family; and the Prince Takamochi lineage, a samurai family, originating with Prince Takamochi who was the son of the Prince Takami (the third son of the Emperor Kanmu) and identified himself as TAIRA no Takamochi when demoted with his father from the Imperial family.
sen.cmt: Added ";" for clarity.
sen.e: This is one of the four Kanmu-Heishi lineages followed by the two well-known lineages: the Prince Takamune lineage of court nobles which originates from Prince Takamune, the first son of the Imperial Prince Kazurawara who was named TAIRA no Takamune on demotion from the Imperial family; and the Prince Takamochi lineage of samurai families which originates from Prince Takamochi, a son of the Prince Takami (the third son of the Imperial Prince Kazurawara) who was named TAIRA no Takamochi on demotion from the Imperial family.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。court小文字にしました。

tit.e: The lineage of the Prince Tanamune

sen.j: 葛原親王の長男で、天長2年（825年）に賜姓を受けて平高棟となった高棟王の子孫。
sen.e: It is a descendant of the Prince Tanamune who was the first son of the Price Kazurawara and became TAIRA no Takamune bestowed a surname in 825.
These are the descendants of Prince Tanamune who was the first son of Prince Kazurawara and became TAIRA no Takamune when bestowed a surname in 825.
sen.cmt: Removed "the"
sen.e: They were the descendants of Prince Takamune, the first son of Imperial Prince Kazurawara who was named TAIRA no Takamune when a surname was conferred in 825.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: この流れは公家として京都に残り、平安時代末期に平清盛（高望王流）の正室平時子（二位尼）と、その弟で清盛の威勢によって正二位大納言にのぼった平時忠、異母妹の建春門院平滋子が出た。
sen.e: This linage remained in Kyoto as kuge (court noble), from which there were TAIRA no Tokiko (Nii no Ama), the lawful wife of TAIRA no Kiyomori (the linage of Prince Takamochi) at the end of the Heian period, TAIRA no Tokitada, her brother, who assigned to Dainagon (Major Counselor) in Shonii (Senior Second Rank) by the power of Kiyomori, and Kenshunmonin TAIRA no Shigeko, her half-sister.

This lineage remained in Kyoto as kuge (court noble), and produced TAIRA no Tokiko (Nii no Ama), the lawful wife of TAIRA no Kiyomori (who was of the Prince Takamochi branch) at the end of the Heian period; TAIRA no Tokitada, her brother, who was appointed Dainagon (Major Counselor) of Shonii (Senior Second Rank) thanks to the influence of Kiyomori; and Kenshunmonin TAIRA no Shigeko, her half-sister.
sen.cmt: Added ";" for clarity.
sen.e: Members of this lineage became court nobles and remained in Kyoto; in the late Heian period, the following prominent figures came from this lineage: TAIRA no Tokiko (Nii no Ama), the lawful wife of TAIRA no Kiyomori (from the lineage of the Prince Takamochi); TAIRA no Tokitada, Tokiko's brother, who was promoted to Dainagon (Major Counselor) of Shonii (Senior Second Rank) owing to Kiyomori's influence; and Kenshunmonin TAIRA no Shigeko, their half-sister.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 時忠は壇ノ浦の合戦後、能登国に流され没落したが、時忠の弟平親宗の子孫（唐橋家）や叔父平信範の子孫（西洞院家・安居院家・烏丸家）は鎌倉時代以降も公家として続いた。
sen.e: Although Tokitada was exiled to the Noto Province and brought to ruin after the Battle of Dan no ura, the descendants of his brother TAIRA no Chikamune (the Karahashi family) and those of his uncle TAIRA no Nobunori (the Nishinotoin family, the Agoin family and the Karasumaru family) remained as kuge even after the Kamakura period.

Although Tokitada was exiled to the Noto Province and ruined after the Battle of Dan no ura, the descendants of his brother TAIRA no Chikamune (the Karahashi family) and those of his uncle TAIRA no Nobunori (the Nishinotoin family, the Agoin family and the Karasumaru family) remained as kuge into and beyond the Kamakura period.
sen.cmt: Changed "brought to ruin" to "ruined".
sen.e: After the Battle of Dan no ura, Tokitada was exiled to the Noto Province and died there, but the descendants of his brother TAIRA no Chikamune (the Karahashi family) and those of his uncle TAIRA no Nobunori (the Nishinotoin family, the Agoin family and the Karasumaru family) survived as court nobles through the Kamakura period.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 特に西洞院家は江戸時代まで続き、分家により同家も含め5家の堂上家を出した。
sen.e: Especially the Nishinotoin family had continued until the Edo period and had led to the five houses of Tosho-ke (the hereditary lineage of Court nobles occupying relatively high ranks) including branch families.

The Nishinotoin family, in particular, continued into the Edo period and, together with its branch families, led to the five houses of Tosho-ke (the hereditary lineage of Court nobles occupying relatively high ranks).
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: The Nishinotoin family in particular survived into the Edo period, and this head family and four branch families became Tosho-ke (the hereditary lineage of court nobles occupying relatively high ranks).
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。court 小文字にしました。

sen.j: なお、時忠の子時国の子孫を称する家が能登半島で豪農（上時国家、下時国家）となり、現在も続いている。
sen.e: In addition, the family which identifies itself as a descendant of Tokikuni, a son of Tokitada, became wealthy farmer (the Kamitokikuni family and the Shimotokikuni family) in the Noto peninsula, and exists even now.

In addition, families identifying themselves as descendants of Tokikuni, a son of Tokitada, (the Kamitokikuni family and the Shimotokikuni family) became wealthy farmers in the Noto peninsula, and exist to this day.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: In addition, families identifying themselves as descendants of Tokikuni, a son of Tokitada, became wealthy farmers in the Noto peninsula (the Kamitokikuni family and the Shimotokikuni family), and exist to this day.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

tit.e: The linage of the Prince Takamochi

sen.j: 葛原親王の三男、高見王の子高望王が賜姓を受けて平高望となったのに始まる家。
sen.e: It originates from the Prince Takamochi, a son of the Prince Takamochi (the third son of the Imperial Prince Kazurawara) was bestowed a surname and identified himself as TAIRA no Takamochi.
This lineage originates with Prince Takamochi, a son of the Prince Takami (the third son of the Imperial Prince Kazurawara) who was bestowed a surname and became TAIRA no Takamochi.
sen.cmt: The third son's name is "Takami".
sen.e: This lineage originated with Prince Takamochi, a son of Prince Takami (the third son of Imperial Prince Kazurawara) who, having been given an honorary surname, was named TAIRA no Takamochi.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 但し、高見王の名は同時代の史料に名前が見えないので系譜には疑問も残る。
sen.e: However, since the name of the Prince Takami is not seen in historical sources at that age, there remains a doubt on its family tree.
However, since the name of the Prince Takami is not seen in contemporary historical sources, questions about this lineage remain.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: However, since the name of the Prince Takami is not found in historical sources from the relevant period, there is some doubt about this lineage.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: （望と見は両方とも名読みで「み」と読める。）
sen.e: (Both '望' and '見' are read as 'mi' in the case of Japanese readings.)
sen.cmt: 「名読み」は「訓読み」と判断しました。
sen.e: (The final characters in Takammochi (望) and Takami (見) can also be read as 'mi' in when readingJapanese names.)
sen.cmt: Added a more detailed explantion about Kanji
sen.e: (Both last kanji characters in Takamochi (望) and Takami (見) can be read as 'mi' in Japanese reading.)
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 寛平元年（889年）に皇族5名が平朝臣を賜姓されたとの記録（個々の名前は伝わらない）があるので、高望王はそのうちの一人と推定されている。
sen.e: Since there is a record that the five Imperial princes were given the surname of 'Taira no Ason' in 889 (each name was not known), the Prince Takami is guessed as one of them.
Since there is a record that five Imperial princes (of unknown name) were given the surname of 'Taira no Ason' in 889, it is supposed that Prince Takami was one of them.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: Based on a record stating that the surname of 'Taira no Ason' was conferred on five imperial princes (of unknown names) in 889, it is assumed that Prince Takamochi was one of them.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 坂東平氏
sen.e: The Bando-Heishi
The Bando-Heishi
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: The Bando-Heishi
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 高望は、昌泰元年（898年）に上総国に任じられた。
sen.e: Takamochi was assumed to be the kokushi (provincial governors) of the Kazusa Province in 898 and went to his posting with his sons TAIRA no Kunika, TAIRA no Yoshikane and TAIRA no Yoshimasa, although many kokushi stayed in Kyoto (called Yonin Kokushi).

Takamochi was appointed as kokushi (provincial governor) of Kazusa Province in 898 and, although many kokushi stayed in Kyoto (so-called Yonin Kokushi), he went to his posting with his sons TAIRA no Kunika, TAIRA no Yoshikane and TAIRA no Yoshimasa.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: Takamochi was appointed as kokushi (provincial governor) of Kazusa Province in 898.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。一原分一訳文例外処理

sen.j: 遥任国司が多いなか、子の平国香・平良兼・平良将を伴い任地に下向した。
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: While many other kokushi stayed in Kyoto (so-called Yonin Kokushi), Takamochi left the capital and went into the province with his sons TAIRA no Kunika, TAIRA no Yoshikane and TAIRA no Yoshimasa.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。一原分一訳文例外処理

sen.j: そして任期が過ぎても帰京せず、国香は常陸大掾、良将は鎮守府将軍を勤めるなどした。
sen.e: And he did not return to Kyoto even after the expiration, Kunika put in charge of Hitachi no daijo (Senior Secretary of Hitachi Province), and Yoshimasa put in charge of Chinju-fu shogun (Commander-in-Chief of the Defense of the North).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: And he did not return to Kyoto after his period office had expired, Kunika becoming Hitachi no daijo (Senior Secretary of Hitachi Province) and Yoshimasa becoming Chinju-fu shogun (Commander-in-Chief of the Defense of the North).
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: Takamochi did not return to Kyoto after he served out his term, and his sons Kunika filled the post of Hitachi no daijo (Senior Secretary of Hitachi Province) and Yoshimasa of Chinju-fu shogun (Commander-in-Chief of the Defense of the North).
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 上総国ばかりでなく常陸国や下総国にも勢力を拡大、坂東に武士団を形成し武家平氏の基盤を固めた。
sen.e: He expanded the power not only in the Kazusa Province but also in the Hitachi Province and the Shimousa Province, formed armed groups in Bando (old Kanto region) and firmed the foundation of the Taira clan as samurai.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Thus, Takamochi expanded his power not only in Kazusa Province but also in Hitachi Province and Shimousa Province, forming armed groups in Bando (old Kanto region) and strengthening the foundations of the Taira clan as samurai.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: They expanded their power from Kazusa Province into Hitachi Province and Shimousa Province, forming armed groups in the Bando (old Kanto) region, which became the foundation of the Taira clan as samurai.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: また、高望の側室の子平良文もその後坂東に下り、良文の子孫も坂東に散らばって三浦氏・土肥氏・秩父氏・千葉氏などの武家となった。
sen.e: In addition, TAIRA no Yoshifumi, the son of Takamochi's concubine, went down to Bando later and his descendants also became samurai families such as the Miura clan, the Dohi clan, the Chichibu clan and the Chiba clan at various places in Bando.

In addition, TAIRA no Yoshifumi, the son of Takamochi's concubine, later left Kyoto for Bando, and his descendants also became samurai families such as the Miura clan, the Dohi clan, the Chichibu clan and the Chiba clan in various locations across Bando.
sen.cmt: I think "坂東に下り" is best translated as left Kyoto for Bando.
sen.e: TAIRA no Yoshifumi, a son of Takamochi's concubine, also left Kyoto for Bando, and his descendants formed samurai clans such as the Miura, Doi, Chichibu and Chiba in various locations across Bando.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 特に良文流の坂東平氏を坂東八平氏という。
sen.e: Especially the Bando-Heishi of the Yoshifumi linage was called Bando Hachi Heishi (the Eight Taira clans of the East).
The Bando-Heishi of the Yoshifumi linage are specifically referred to as the Bando Hachi Heishi (the Eight Taira clans of the East).
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: The Bando-Heishi of the Yoshifumi linage are specifically referred to as the Bando Hachi Heishi (the Eight Taira Clans of the East).
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 伊勢平氏と平家
sen.e: The Ise-Heishi and Heike
The Ise-Heishi and Heike
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: The Ise-Heishi and Heike
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 国香の孫平維衡よりはじまる一族が伊勢平氏である。
sen.e: The clan originated from TAIRA no Korehira, the grandson of Kunika, is called the Ise-Heishi.
The clan originating with TAIRA no Korehira, the grandson of Kunika, is called the Ise-Heishi.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: TAIRA no Korehira, a grandson of Kunika, was the founder of a clan called the Ise-Heishi.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 平氏の中でも伊勢平氏、特に平正盛の系統を平家（へいけ）と呼ぶ。
sen.e: The Ise-Heishi, especially the linage of TAIRA no Masamori, is called Heike among the Taira clan.
The Ise-Heishi of the Taira clan, and especially the lineage of TAIRA no Masamori, are called the Heike.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: The Ise-Heishi branch of the Taira clan, and those descended from TAIRA no Masamori in particular, are specifically called the Heike (Taira family).
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 正盛の子平忠盛が初めて昇殿を許され、忠盛の子清盛は平氏政権を樹立し栄華を誇ったが、驕る平家は久しからず、壇ノ浦の戦いで滅亡した。
sen.e: TAIRA no Tadamori, the son of Masamori, was first permitted the access to the Imperial court and his son Kiyomori established the government of the Taira clan and flourished, but it went to ruin at the Battle of Dan no ura, which is said as the proud and arrogant Heike does not last forever.

TAIRA no Tadamori, the son of Masamori, was the first in the family to be permitted access to the Imperial court and his son Kiyomori established a Taira government and became extremely powerful, but the proud and arrogant Heike were not to last for long and were destroyed at the Battle of Dan no ura.
sen.cmt: An awful lot of ground is covered in one sentence here.
sen.e: Masanori's son, TAIRA no Tadamori, was the first member of the family to be granted access to the Imperial court, and Tadamori's son (Kiyomori) established the Heike-dominated government and became extremely powerful; the proud and arrogant Heike were not to last for long, however, and they were destroyed in the Battle of Dan no ura.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 各地に散らばって隠れ住んだ平家の落人の子孫を自称する武家は大変多く、代表的なものとして薩摩国の種子島氏、対馬国の宗氏、尾張国の織田氏などが挙げられる。
sen.e: Many samurai families identified themselves as the descendants of Heike no Ochiudo (fugitives from Genpei War) who lived secretly and separately in various places, among whom the Tanegashima clan in the Satsuma Province, the So clan in the Tsushima Province and the Oda clan in the Owari Province are well-known.

Many samurai families identified themselves as the descendants of Heike no Ochiudo (Heike fugitives from Genpei War) who lived secretly and separately in various locations throughout the country, some examples being the Tanegashima clan in Satsuma Province, the So clan in Tsushima Province and the Oda clan in Owari Province.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: Heike no Ochiudo (Heike fugitives from the Genpei War) scattered across the country to live their lives in secrecy, and many samurai families that identified themselves as descendants of the Ochiudo included the Tanegashima clan in Satsuma Province, the So clan in Tsushima Province, and the Oda clan in Owari Province.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: しかし、これらは子孫だとしても平家一族の子孫ではなく、平家に仕えた郎党の子孫というべきだろう（織田氏については藤原氏説もあり）。
sen.e: However, they were not the descendants of the Heike family even if they were really the descendants, and it should be said that they were the descendants of roto (retainer) who served Heike (in another theory, the Oda clan is regarded as the descendant of the Fujiwara clan).

However, even if it is accepted that these clans had links stretching back the Heike family, their descendants were likely to have been roto (retainer) who served Heike rather than the of the Heike family itself (for the Oda clan, there is also a theory that they were descendants of the Fujiwara clan).
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: However, these are likely to have been descendants of retainers who served the Heike, rather than actual members of the Heike family (according to another theory, the Oda clan was descended from the Fujiwara clan).
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 熊本県の五家荘や富山県の五箇山などは平家の落人の隠れ里と伝えられる。
sen.e: Gokanosho in the Kumamoto Prefecture, Gokayama in the Toyama Prefecture and others are said to be the hidden places of Heike no Ochiudo.
Examples of the hidden villages of the Heike no Ochiudo include Gokanosho in Kumamoto Prefecture, Gokayama in Toyama Prefecture
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: Examples of the hiding villages of the Heike no Ochiudo include Gokanosho in Kumamoto Prefecture and Gokayama in Toyama Prefecture.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: これら平家の落武者およびその家族、使用人等の隠れ里と伝わる地を「平家谷」と通称する。
sen.e: These places which are called the hidden places of a surviving soldier (of a defeated army) of Heike, his family and retainers, are commonly called 'Heike-dani (villages of Heike fugitives).'
These villages where the surviving Heike fighters, their families and retainers hid themselves are commonly called 'Heike-dani (villages of Heike fugitives).'
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: These so-called hiding villages for the surviving Heike fighters, their families and retainers are commonly called 'Heike-dani (villages of Heike fugitives).'
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 室町時代に入ると『平家物語』が完成し、今日まで広く愛される軍記物語となった。
sen.e: In the Muromachi period, "Heike Monogatari" (The tale of the Heike) was completed and has been read widely as a war chronicle until now.
The Muromachi period saw the completion of the "Heike Monogatari" (The tale of the Heike) which continues to be widely read as a war chronicle today.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: The Muromachi period saw the completion of the "Heike Monogatari" (The Tale of the Heike), an epic account of the Genpei War that has been widely read up to this day.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。余分なスペースを削除しました。

sen.j: 仁明天皇の孫・雅望王、行忠王及び惟時王の子孫が平朝臣を賜姓されて臣籍に下ることによって成立した氏族。
sen.e: It is the clan which originated from the descendants of Prince Masamochi, Prince Yukitada and Prince Koretoki who were the grandchildren of the Emperor Ninmyo, and founded by being bestowed the surname of Taira no Ason and demoted from the Imperial family to subject.

This clan originated when the descendents of Prince Masamochi, Prince Yukitada and Prince Koretoki (the grandchildren of the Emperor Ninmyo) were demoted from the Imperial family and bestowed the surname of Taira no Ason.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: This clan originated with the descendents of Prince Masamochi, Prince Yukitada, and Prince Koretoki (all of whom were grandsons of Emperor Ninmyo), who were given the honorary surname of Taira no Ason upon being demoted from the Imperial family.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: なお「仁明天皇の皇子・本康親王の子孫が「平朝臣」を賜姓されて臣籍に下ることによって成立した氏族」を仁明平氏と定義している文献もある。
sen.e: In addition, some literature define the Nimyo-Heishi as 'the clan originated from the descendant of the Imperial Prince Motoyasu, the son of the Emperor Ninmyo, by being bestowed the surname of 'Taira no Ason' and demoted from the Imperial family to subject,' but since even some princes of the Imperial Prince Motoyasu were given the surname of Minamoto and became the Nimyo-Genji such as MINAMOTO no Kaneji (源兼似), MINAMOTO no Kanehito (源兼仁), MINAMOTO no Chogan (源朝鑑), MINAMOTO no Yasumochi (源保望), and MINAMOTO no Yoshimichi (源由道), it is adequate to say that the descendants of Prince Masamochi, Prince Yukitada and Prince Koretoki are the Ninmyo-Heishi.
sen.cmt: 「源兼似,源朝鑑・源朝憲・源保望・源由道」の読み方不明です。
sen.e: Note that although some literature defines the Nimyo-Heishi as 'the clan originating with the descendants of Imperial Prince Motoyasu, the son of the Emperor Ninmyo, who were demoted from the Imperial family and bestowed the surname of 'Taira no Ason'', this is unlikely because even close relations of Imperial Prince Motoyasu were given the surname of Minamoto and became Nimyo-Genji (e.g MINAMOTO no Kaneji (源兼似), MINAMOTO no Kanehito (源兼仁), MINAMOTO no Chogan (源朝鑑), MINAMOTO no Yasumochi (源保望), and MINAMOTO no Yoshimichi (源由道)), and it is therefore correct to specify the descendants of Prince Masamochi, Prince Yukitada and Prince Koretoki as being the Ninmyo-Heishi.
sen.cmt: It is not clear what "princes of Imperial Prince Minamoto" means. I have changed this to "close relations of.." which seems to fit the context.
sen.e: It should be noted that some documents define the Ninmyo-Heishi as 'the clan originating with the descendants of Imperial Prince Motoyasu, a son of Emperor Ninmyo, who were given the surname of 'Taira no Ason' upon being demoted from the Imperial family.'
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: しかし、本康親王の皇子でも源兼似・源兼仁・源朝鑑・源朝憲・源保望・源由道のように源朝臣を賜姓されて仁明源氏となった者もいる。
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: This definition is implausible because some of Imperial Prince Motoyasu's sons were given the surname of Minamoto no Ason and became Ninmyo-Genji, such as MINAMOTO no Kaneji (源兼似), MINAMOTO no Kanehito (源兼仁), MINAMOTO no Chogan (源朝鑑), MINAMOTO no Yasumochi (源保望), and MINAMOTO no Yoshimichi (源由道).
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。一原文一訳文例外処理

sen.j: このため、正確には雅望王・行忠王・惟時王の子孫が仁明平氏である。
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: It is therefore correct to define the descendants of Prince Masamochi, Prince Yukitada and Prince Koretoki as the Ninmyo-Heishi.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。一原文一訳文例外処理

sen.j: 文徳天皇の皇子・惟彦親王の子孫が平朝臣を賜姓されて臣籍に下ることによって成立した氏族。
sen.e: It is the clan originated from the descendant of the Imperial Prince Korehiko, the prince of the Emperor Montoku, who was bestowed the surname of Taira no Ason and demoted from the Imperial family to subject.
This clan originated with the descendants of Imperial Prince Korehiko, the son of Emperor Montoku, who were bestowed the surname of Taira no Ason and demoted from the Imperial family.
sen.cmt: Here again, the meaning of "the prince of Emperor Montoku" is unclear. I have changed this to "the son of..".
sen.e: This clan originated with the descendants of Imperial Prince Korehiko (Emperor Montoku's son), who were given the honorary surname of Taira no Ason upon being demoted from the Imperial family.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 光孝天皇の孫・式膽王及び興我王の子孫が平朝臣を賜姓されて臣籍に下ることによって成立した氏族。
sen.e: It is the clan originated from the descendant of Prince Shikisen and Prince Koga (興我王), the grandchildren of the Emperor Koko, who was bestowed the surname of Taira no Ason and demoted from the Imperial family to subject.
sen.cmt: 「興我王」の読み方不明です。
sen.e: This clan originated with the descendants of Prince Shikisen and Prince Koga (興我王), the grandchildren of the Emperor Koko, who were bestowed the surname of Taira no Ason and demoted from the Imperial family.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: This clan originated with descendants of Prince Shikisen and Prince Koga (grandchildren of Emperor Koko), who were given the honorary surname of Taira no Ason upon being demoted from the Imperial family.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: なお「光孝天皇の皇子・是忠親王の子孫が「平朝臣」を賜姓されて臣籍に下ることによって成立した氏族」を光孝平氏と定義している文献もある。
sen.e: In addition, some literature define the Koko-Heishi as 'the clan originated from the descendant of the Imperial Prince Koretada, the son of the Emperor Koko, by being bestowed the surname of 'Taira no Ason' and demoted from the Imperial family to subject,' but since even some descendants of the Imperial Prince Koretada were bestowed the surname of Minamoto no Ason and became the Koko-Genji such as MINAMOTO no Yasunao (源康尚) (the son of MINAMOTO no Yasuyuki. Prince Eiga (英我王), the grandfather of Yasunao was the son of the Imperial Prince Koretada), it is adequate to say that the descendants of Prince Shikisen and Prince Koga are the Koko-Heishi.
sen.cmt: 「源康尚」、「英我王」の読み方不明です。
sen.e: Note that while some literature defines the Koko-Heishi as 'the clan originating with the descendants of the Imperial Prince Koretada, the son of the Emperor Koko, who were bestowed the surname of 'Taira no Ason' and demoted from the Imperial family', but this is unlikely because even some descendants of the Imperial Prince Koretada were bestowed the surname of Minamoto no Ason and became the Koko-Genji (e.g. MINAMOTO no Yasunao (源康尚),who was the son of MINAMOTO no Yasuyuki and grandson of Prince Eiga (英我王), the son of the Imperial Prince Koretada), and it therefore correct to specify the descendants of Prince Shikisen and Prince Koga as the Koko-Heishi.
sen.cmt: Clarified. Also "In addition" doesn't really work here.
sen.e: It should be noted that some documents define the Koko-Heishi as 'the clan originating with the descendants of Imperial Prince Koretada, a son of Emperor Koko, who were given the surname of 'Taira no Ason' upon being demoted from the Imperial family.'
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。一原文一訳文例外処理余分なスペース削除しました。

sen.j: しかし、是忠親王の子孫でも源康尚（源康行の子。康尚の祖父・英我王は是忠親王の子）のように源朝臣を賜姓されて光孝源氏となった者もいる。
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: This definition is implausible because some descendants of Imperial Prince Koretada who were given the surname 'Minamoto no Ason' became the Koko-Genji; an example of this is MINAMOTO no Yasunao, a son of MINAMOTO no Yasuyuki, whose grandfather Prince Eiga was a son of Imperial Prince Koretada.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。一原文一訳文例外処理余分なスペース削除しました。The kanji isn't necessary here.

sen.j: このため、正確には式膽王及び興我王の子孫が光孝平氏である。
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: It is therefore correct to define the descendants of Prince Shikisen and Prince Koga as the Koko-Heishi.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。一原文一訳文例外処理

sen.j: また、平高棟の孫・平中興は是忠親王の子・忠望王の養子になったため、血筋からみると高棟王流桓武平氏だが中興の子孫は光孝平氏である。
sen.e: In addition, TAIRA no Nakaki, the grandchild of TAIRA no Takamune, became an adopted son of Prince Tadamochi, the son of Imperial Prince Koretada, so that he was classified into the Kanmu-Heishi of the Prince Takamune linage on the blood line, but his descendant was Koko-Heishi.

In addition, TAIRA no Nakaki, the grandchild of TAIRA no Takamune, was adopted by Prince Tadamochi, the son of Imperial Prince Koretada, and was therefore added into the Prince Takamune lineage of the Kanmu-Heishi, but his descendants were Koko-Heishi.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: TAIRA no Nakaki, the grandchild of TAIRA no Takamune, was adopted by Prince Tadamochi, a son of Imperial Prince Koretada, and therefore added into the Prince Takamune lineage of the Kanmu-Heishi, but Nakaki's descendants were Koko-Heishi.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 従って平元規（中興の子）も光孝平氏である。
sen.e: Therefore, TAIRA no Motonori (the son of Nakaki) was also Koko-Heishi.
Hence, TAIRA no Motonori (the son of Nakaki) was Koko-Heishi.
sen.cmt: I don't think "also" is required here.
sen.e: Hence, TAIRA no Motonori (the son of Nakaki) was Koko-Heishi.
sen.cmt: 修正なし
